title: Betty Grier
author: Waugh, Joseph Laing
snippet: He lost his temper, and bluntly asked me if, for a moment, I, aprospectless student and son of a provincial merchant, considered myselfworthy of a Kennedy of Knockshaw; whereupon I told him that there wereGriersons in Lag, as wardens of the Border Marches, when the Kennedyswere sitting in farmyard barns making spoons out of ram-horns.

title: Betty Grier
author: Waugh, Joseph Laing
snippet: 'I've heard it said, doctor, that ye kenned the Kennedys aince on atime,' said Betty, and she changed the position of a pot of musk on thewindow-sill.

title: Waverley; Or, 'Tis Sixty Years Since
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: In 1808, as appears from an undated letter toSurtees of Mainsforth (Abbotsford Manuscripts), he was contemplating apoem on "that wandering knight so fair," Charles Edward, and on theadventures of his flight, on Lochiel, Flora Macdonald, the Kennedys, andthe rest.

title: Reheated Cabbage
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: — Wir talkin abootthe fuckin Kennedys, ya tube!

title: Reheated Cabbage
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: — Naw . . . the Kennedys came fae Boston.That wis thairhome toon.

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: " She sings those dear old Scotch songs quite as well asHelen Kirk or the Kennedys," replied Janet enthusiastically.

title: Story of Maurice Lestrange. Being an account of his travels and adventures in Scotland during the year 1765. [A tale.]
author: Omond, George William Thomson.
snippet: Alexander Arbuthnot might haveno family; and in that case, should there also be nooffspring of the Laird's marriage, nothing would standbetween the Kennedys and the succession but theprecarious life of Francis.

title: Story of Maurice Lestrange. Being an account of his travels and adventures in Scotland during the year 1765. [A tale.]
author: Omond, George William Thomson.
snippet: The Kennedys were a curious couple.
